rule.name: Determiner/noun agreement
rule.message: For plural nouns, use the plural article the.
rule.example: The baseball teams were successful.
A baseball teams were successful.

rule.name: Noun/Verb agreement
rule.example: xxx
xxx

rule.name: Word order: 'Can...'
rule.example: Can someone reproduce that?
Does someone can reproduce that?

rule.name: Word order: 'a more (adj)'
rule.example: I can give you more a detailed description of what's necessary.
I can give you more a detailed description of what's necessary.

rule.name: Confusion of a/are
rule.example: Some would think you are a fortunate man.
Some would think you a fortunate man.

rule.name: Confusion of extend/extent
rule.message: Did you mean extent ("extent" is a noun, "extend" is a verb)?
rule.example: Yes it is, to a certain extent.
Yes it is, to a certain extend.

rule.name: Confusion of were/where
rule.example: Now, this is where my ignorance sets in.
Now, this is were my ignorance sets in.

rule.name: Confusion of ore/or
rule.example: Type in one or more words.
Type in one ore more words.

rule.name: Confusion of on/one
rule.message: Did you mean the only one?
rule.example: The trash folder is the only one for me that works.
The trash folder is the only on for me that works.

rule.name: Confusion of their/there
rule.example: He noticed that there is a new test.
He noticed that their is a new test.

rule.name: Confusion of a/am
rule.message: Did you mean am (first person of "to be")?
rule.example: I am not sure.
I a not sure.

rule.name: Confusion of new/knew
rule.message: Did you mean knew (past of "to know")?
rule.example: Ah, I knew you would say that.
Ah, I new you would say that.

rule.name: Confusion of not/note
rule.example: Please note that saying "Open Source" does not mean very much.
Please not that saying "Open Source" does not mean very much.

rule.name: Confusion of nut/not
rule.example: I'm not sure.
I'm nut sure.

rule.name: Confusion of one/on
rule.message: Did you mean and so on (="etc.")?
rule.example: We think it helps finding bottlenecks and so on.
We think it helps finding bottlenecks and so one.

rule.name: Confusion of through/throw
rule.example: Or we just throw away all bugs.
Or we just through away all bugs.

rule.name: Confusion of way/was
rule.example: Or was that a very recent change in Qt?
Or way that a very recent change in Qt?

rule.name: Confusion of responds/response
rule.example: Thanks for the response.
Thanks for the responds.

rule.name: Confusion off/of
rule.example: It's the only part of KDE I know of that uses automasking.
It's the only part of KDE I know off that uses automasking.

rule.name: Confusion us/use
rule.example: Please don't use dispose.
Please don't us dispose.

rule.name: Past tense of 'used to...'
rule.message: Use the past tense to build a sentence with "to use".
rule.example: Aethera used to use this.
Aethera use to use this.

rule.name: Confusion thing/think
rule.message: Did you mean think or thinks?
rule.example: I think that's a good idea.
I thing that's a good idea.

rule.name: Confusion of were/where/we
rule.message: Did you mean where or we?
rule.example: We are in the process of implementing this.
Were are in the process of implementing this.

rule.name: Confusion of it/is
rule.example: ...which it wasn't the last day.
...which is wasn't the last day.

rule.name: Confusion of fore/for
rule.example: Thanks again for your help.
Thanks again fore your help.

rule.name: Confusion of too/two
rule.example: Ideally we should have one database, not two.
Ideally we should have one database, not too.

rule.name: Confusion of your/you're
rule.message: Did you mean you're or you are?
rule.example: I think you're confused.
I think your confused.

rule.name: Confusion of that/than
rule.example: I am not wiser than you.
I am not wiser that you.

rule.name: Confusion of then/than
rule.example: It's less controversial than one would think.
It's less controversial then one would think.

rule.name: Two consecutive articles
rule.example: The thing is this.
The the thing is this.

rule.name: Confusion of than/then
rule.example: I volunteer to create a testcase then.
I volunteer to create a testcase than.

rule.name: Confusion of 'of cause/of course'
rule.example: The law of cause and effect.
Of course all these things are relative.
Of cause all these things are relative.

rule.name: Infinitive verb with 'eager to...'
rule.message: Use the base form of the verb with eager to.
rule.example: I'd be eager to try out your patch.
I'd be eager to trying out your patch.

rule.name: Sentence ending in 'or'
rule.message: Don't end a sentence with or. If you want to ask for confirmation, use isn't it, don't you etc.
rule.example: I think we should meet soon, don't you?
I think we should meet soon, or?

rule.name: Useless article before 'much'
rule.example: This will be much work.
This will be a much work.

rule.name: No 'more' or 'most' before superlatives
rule.message: Remove 'most' or 'more' when you use the superlative.
rule.example: Kyoto is the oldest city.
Kyoto is the most oldest city.

rule.name: Confusion of is/it
rule.example: I definitely think it should be less than four years.
I definitely think is should be less than four years.
This allows to provide the powerful help system.
This allows to provide the powerful a help system.
This allows to provide a powerful help system.
This allows to provide a powerful a help system.

rule.name: Third person verb with 'he'
rule.message: Third person singular noun requires verb with '-s'.
rule.example: Then he looks at the building.
Then he look at the building.

rule.name: Infinitive verb after 'did'
rule.example: Peter did go to the cinema.
Peter did went to the cinema.
He did walked to his house.
He did walking to his house.

rulegroup.name: Infinitive verb after auxiliary verb
rulegroup.message: Modal verbs like 'will'/'might'/... require base form of verb.

rule.example: John will talk to her.
John will go home.
John will goes home.
John will walks home.
John will walked home.
Mr Kulow might help me.
Mr Kulow might helps me.
Mr Kulow might talk to me.
Mr Kulow might talked to me.
John will go home.
John will walks home.
He is walking home.
He is go home.
The ball was catched by John.
The ball was catch by John.

rule.name: Comparison with 'as'
rule.example: This house is as big as mine.
This house is as big like mine.
This house is as big than mine.
This box contains as much as possible.
This box contains as much like possible.

rule.name: Confusion of from/form
rule.example: Type in the form on the web page.
Type in the from on the web page.

rule.name: Misspelling 'cannot'
rule.message: Can + not is written as cannot.
rule.example: You cannot use the keyboard to select an item.
You can not use the keyboard to select an item.
The tagger will return more than one tag.
The tagger will return more then one tag.
This house is bigger than mine.
This house is bigger then mine.

rulegroup.name: Confusion of its/it's
rulegroup.message: Did you maybe mix up it's (=it is) and its (=possessive pronoun)?

rule.example: It's where people walk around.
Its where people walk around.
London is a necropolis, its every corner the site of a murder, its soil a pudding of blood and tears.
It's going to be difficult.
Its going to be difficult.
It's a good opportunity.
Its a good opportunity.
Currently, there are fifteen records on its A list and twenty on its B list.

rulegroup.name: Confusion of no/now
rulegroup.message: Did you maybe mix up no (negation) and now (=at this moment)?

rule.example: There now will be a park.
There no will be a park.
There's now a new building.
There's no a new building.
No no, he said.
Now is the the right time.
No is the the right time.
